{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3124089,"name":"Weaver Goldman","username":"GoldMonster","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/goldmonster/{size}/154153_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-12T11:09:16.816Z","cooked":"

We have been working with swerve for a while, but always worked around this issue.

While the rotation of the pose is correct (0 degrees), and the robot is pointed downfield, it drives correctly, away from the driver station. This is in field relative mode.

However, the estimated pose of the robot (visualized in advantagescope) moves in the opposite direction.

Of course this problem persists to autos, where we have to treat 180 degrees as forward so that it drives and turns correctly.

Perhaps this is the intended way for the pose estimator to work, but even if it is, the behavior is unintuitive and not compatible with our software goals.

Here is a link to our current code if that would be of help:

GitHub

GitHub - FRC2539/javabot-2023: Team 2539's robot code for the 2023 season:...

My team had a similar issue at one point, make sure all of your angles are counter-clockwise, including swerve module angles.
